turns.content: A prime number is a positive integer greater than 1 that is divisible by only 1 and itself. Examples of prime numbers include 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, and 13.

A prime number is a whole number greater than 1 that is divisible by only 1 and itself. For example, the number 5 is prime because it can only be divided evenly by 1 and 5. The number 6, on the other hand, is not prime because it can be divided evenly by 1, 2, 3, and 6. Prime numbers play an important role in number theory and have many applications in mathematics and computer science.

Divisible means that a number can be divided by another number without any remainder. For example, the number 10 is divisible by 5 because 10 / 5 = 2 with no remainder.
Another example, 12 is divisible by 4 because 12/4=3 with no remainder.
In other words, if a number "A" is exactly divisible by another number "B" then we say that "A" is divisible by "B" or "A" is a multiple of "B" or "A" is a factor of "B"
so prime number can only be devited by 1

That is correct. A prime number is a positive integer greater than 1 that is divisible by only 1 and itself. This means that the only factors of a prime number are 1 and the number itself, so it can only be divided evenly by 1 and itself. For example, the number 5 is prime because the only numbers that divide into it without leaving a remainder are 1 and 5.
how do i find if my number if it over 100

If you want to determine if a number is greater than 100, you can simply compare it to 100 using a relational operator such as "greater than" (>).
For example, if you have a variable x that holds a number, you can use the following code:
```
if x > 100:
    print("x is greater than 100")
else:
    print("x is not greater than 100")
```
You can also use other relational operators like <, >=, <=, ==, != to compare your number with 100 to see if it is greater, less, equal or not equal to 100.
```
if x >= 100:
    print("x is greater than or equal to 100")
```
Or
```
if x < 100:
    print("x is less than 100")
```
Note that the relational operator '>=' will test whether the number is greater than or equal to 100 and '<=' will test whether the number is less than or equal to 100.

No, 36 is not a prime number. It can be divided evenly by other numbers besides 1 and itself. For example, 36 can be divided evenly by 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 12 and 36, so it is not a prime number.
36= 2x2x3x3
It is not just divisible by 1 and 36.

No, 81 is not a prime number. It can be divided evenly by other numbers besides 1 and itself. For example, 81 can be divided evenly by 1, 3, 9, and 81, so it is not a prime number.
81= 3x3x3x1
It is not just divisible by 1 and 81.

No, 154 is not a prime number. It can be divided evenly by other numbers besides 1 and itself. For example, 154 can be divided evenly by 1, 2, 7, 11 and 154, so it is not a prime number.
154= 2x7x11
It is not just divisible by 1 and 154.
